philosophy:
For me, art is not a reflection of reality, but a confrontation with it. I believe that true artistic expression should be an interrogation of the systems and ideologies that govern our lives, rather than a mere representation of the world as we know it. My work aims to disrupt the complacency that comes from embracing the status quo, instead opting for a provocative exploration of the grey areas between critique and convention – where art can be both a powerful tool for social commentary and a personal, emotional experience.

As an artist, I've always been drawn to the uncomfortable, the unspoken, and the unwritten rules that govern our society. I see my work as a way to peel back the layers of superficiality and expose the underlying structures that shape our perceptions
backstory:
She had spent years questioning the notion of artistic expression, her work often hovering at the precipice of critique and convention. A pivotal moment came when, as an undergraduate student, she was tasked with creating a thesis installation that probed the intersection of consumerism and social control; the experience culminated in a sprawling, site-specific sculpture made from discarded fast-fashion materials, its deliberately mundane appearance serving to highlight the banality of systems designed to exploit.

This work had forever altered her approach, imbuing every subsequent piece with an undercurrent of intellectual inquiry and meta-commentary. Her studio became a sanctum where ideas wrestled with craft, where concepts took precedence over decorative embellishments and the artist's own voice remained an elusive whisper amidst the din of provocative
